summary: I only act so I can afford to help charities, says Michael Sheen
title: I only act so I can afford to help charities, says Michael Sheen
excerpt: Michael Sheen said he now only acts to support his charitable work, as he visited a project that helps young disadvantaged Londoners. The actor has used earnings from hit shows like Masters of Sex and films such as The Special Relationship to spend 10 years travelling around the world visiting grassroots projects and social enterprises.

title: Hollywood star launches homeless helpline
excerpt: Wales' first national out-of-hours helpline for young people facing homelessness has been launched.

summary: I've just finished watching the film The Adventurer: The Curse of the Midas Box, which Michael Sheen is in, and honestly this is...
body: I’ve just finished watching the film The Adventurer: The Curse of the Midas Box, which Michael Sheen is in, and honestly this is now my headcanon of what Aziraphale was doing before running the bookshop: running around being a badass superspy, beating up bad guys and sassing, under the name Captain Will Charity

blog.name: siegeperilousgalahad
blog.title: Hell is empty and all the devils are here

title: Apostle (2018)
body:
A claustrophobic, folk, horror film set at the dawn of 20th century that highlights mysticism and the neverending barbarisms people are prone to. This movie is not for the faint hearted as it contains extensive violence and gory scenes.

The story follows Thomas who decides to sneak into society of a religous cult after he finds out that his sister has been kidnapped by them. His mission is far from an easy one and his journey gives off ominous vibes from the beginning. 

Our hero isn’t the typical wide eyed good lad we usually encounter on thriller films. He’s a seasoned, leery man and a drug addict. He carries his own demons and he has been through hell and back.

Likewise, the cult leader Malcolm isn’t a two dimensional character. He’s a visionary who truly believes that he does the best for the survival of his community. But is this enough to justify the horrors that happen in the shadows of his religious utopia?

Dan Stevens is solid as Thomas, as he handles masterfully the crazy eyed look. On most scenes he looks like a nervous creature, half animal half man. He navigates the scenes with the horrific awereness of someone who has already experienced pure terror in the past. Michael Sheen is equally good as the conflicted leader of the cult. Lucy Boynton also gives a genuine performance and while her character isn’t as crucial as the other two, the way she embodies it manages to make it a memorable one.

Matt Flannery’s cimatography gives the film the feel of a twisted fairy tale - you know, one with a lot of added brutal and terrifying scenes. As for Gareth Evans, the film’s director, he’s skilled into building moments of tension which lead to an efficient conclusion.

People who enjoyed films like The Witch (2015) or Black Death (2010) will probably also like this movie as they all share the same dark and spooky feeling while dealing with religious subjects.

blog.name: poetictouch
blog.title: Poetictouch
blog.description: Poetry lifts the veil from the hidden beauty of the world. ~ Shelley

summary:
Ozymandias
by Percy Bysshe Shelley (1792-1822)
Read by Michael Sheen

I met a traveller from an antique land
Who said: "Two...
caption:
Ozymandias
by Percy Bysshe Shelley (1792-1822)
Read by Michael Sheen

I met a traveller from an antique land
Who said: “Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
Stand in the desert. Near them, on the sand,
Half sunk, a shattered visage lies, whose frown,
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed.
And on the pedestal these words appear:
‘My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings:
Look on my works, ye mighty, and despair!’
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away.”

blog.name: poetictouch
blog.title: Poetictouch
blog.description: Poetry lifts the veil from the hidden beauty of the world. ~ Shelley

summary:
Ode On Melancholy
by John Keats (1795-1821)
Read by Michael Sheen

No, no! go not to Lethe, neither twist
Wolf's-bane,...
caption:
Ode On Melancholy
by John Keats (1795-1821)
Read by Michael Sheen

No, no! go not to Lethe, neither twist
Wolf’s-bane, tight-rooted, for its poisonous wine;
Nor suffer thy pale forehead to be kiss’d
By nightshade, ruby grape of Proserpine;
Make not your rosary of yew-berries,
Nor let the beetle, nor the death-moth be
Your mournful Psyche, nor the downy owl
A partner in your sorrow’s mysteries;
For shade to shade will come too drowsily,
And drown the wakeful anguish of the soul.

But when the melancholy fit shall fall
Sudden from heaven like a weeping cloud,
That fosters the droop-headed flowers all,
And hides the green hill in an April shroud;
Then glut thy sorrow on a morning rose,
Or on the rainbow of the salt sand-wave,
Or on the wealth of globèd peonies;
Or if thy mistress some rich anger shows,
Emprison her soft hand, and let her rave,
And feed deep, deep upon her peerless eyes.

She dwells with Beauty – Beauty that must die;
And Joy, whose hand is ever at his lips
Bidding adieu; and aching Pleasure nigh,
Turning to poison while the bee-mouth sips:
Ay, in the very temple of Delight
Veil’d Melancholy has her sovran shrine,
Though seen of none save him whose strenuous tongue
Can burst Joy’s grape against his palate fine;
His soul shall taste the sadness of her might,
And be among her cloudy trophies hung.
